# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[621, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 278, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 278, 907, 294]]<|/det|>
9709/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 50 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 215, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 640, 92]]<|/det|>
Points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates (5, 2) and (10, \(-1\)) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 589, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 504, 186, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 710, 523]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the circle with centre \(A\) which passes through \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 505, 920, 524]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The first, second and third terms of an arithmetic progression are \(a, 2a\) and \(a^2\) respectively, where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 537, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the sum of the first 50 terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 824, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the equation \(8x^{2} + kx + 2 = 0\) has no real roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 510, 667, 529]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(8\cos^{2}\theta - 10\cos \theta +2 = 0\) for \(0^{\circ}\leqslant \theta \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A geometric progression is such that the third term is 1764 and the sum of the second and third terms is 3444.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 275, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the 50th term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The graph with equation \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) is transformed to the graph with equation \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\) by a stretch in the \(x\)-direction with factor 0.5, followed by a translation of \(\binom{0}{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 133, 542, 152]]<|/det|>
The diagram below shows the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 164, 520, 183]]<|/det|>
On the diagram sketch the graph of \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 207, 907, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 148, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 470, 510, 488]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{g}(x)\) in terms of \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 470, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graph of \(y = 4x^{2} + 20x + 6\) showing the coordinates of the stationary point. You are not required to indicate where the curve crosses the \(x\)- and \(y\)-axes. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 148, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 895, 104]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact solutions of the equation \(\frac{\sin \theta}{\sin \theta + \cos \theta} + \frac{\cos \theta}{\sin \theta - \cos \theta} = 2\) for \(0 \leqslant \theta \leqslant \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 98, 918, 116]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 517, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinate of the stationary point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 739, 186, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 739, 662, 757]]<|/det|>
State the set of values of \(x\) for which \(y\) increases as \(x\) increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 739, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 376, 92]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 98, 598, 135]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = x + \frac{1}{x}\quad \mathrm{for} x > 0,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 133, 601, 152]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = ax + 1\quad \mathrm{for} x\in \mathbb{R},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 160, 295, 177]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 146, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 191, 390, 208]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{gf}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 191, 920, 208]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 400, 143, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 400, 492, 419]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{gf}(2) = 11\), find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 419]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 643, 141, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 643, 920, 676]]<|/det|>
Given that the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) has a minimum point when \(x = 1\), explain whether or not f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 655, 920, 673]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 348, 91]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that \(a = 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 149, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 106, 514, 123]]<|/det|>
Find and simplify an expression for \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}\mathrm{f}(\mathrm{x})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 608, 185, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 608, 620, 625]]<|/det|>
Explain why the composite function fg cannot be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 607, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 83, 757, 483]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a cross-section \(RASB\) of the body of an aircraft. The cross-section consists of a sector \(OARB\) of a circle of radius \(2.5 \mathrm{m}\), with centre \(O\), a sector \(PASB\) of another circle of radius \(2.24 \mathrm{m}\) with centre \(P\) and a quadrilateral \(OAPB\). Angle \(AOB = \frac{2}{3}\pi\) and angle \(APB = \frac{5}{6}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 565, 146, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 564, 900, 584]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the cross-section \(RASB\), giving your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 580, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 477, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
A point \(P\) is moving along the curve \(y = 18 - \frac{3}{8} x^{\frac{5}{2}}\) in such a way that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is increasing at a constant rate of 2 units per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 523, 702, 543]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which the \(y\)-coordinate of \(P\) is changing when \(x = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 524, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
